item.description:
Saving the Best for Last:

We had explored manyÂ beautiful caves at Ajanta on theÂ first day. But Caves 1, 2, 9, and 10 — some of the most popular ones — were on our list for the second day. Yes, we had saved the best for last. From the spectacular murals of Vajrapani and Padmapani in Cave 1 to the rock stupa and beautiful artÂ in Cave 10, the treasures didn’t cease to amaze us.

The Ajanta Caves. Maharashtra, India.

 

Day 2,Â Entering StorylandÂ at the Ajanta Caves:

We were entranced by the variety of paintings and stories depicted here.

The thrill onÂ sightingÂ the mural of Padmapani holding a water lily, the delight on recognizing aÂ Jataka tale depicted on the wall, the mixed feelings on spottingÂ John Smith’sÂ name carved inside Cave 10… it was a day to remember!

Here are some photographs from our second day at the remarkable Ajanta Caves, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Details about each cave are available at AjantaCaves.com and Wikipedia.

 

Padmapani, holding a water lily. Cave 1, Ajanta Caves, India.

The important sights witnessed by Prince Siddhartha. Ajanta Caves, Maharashtra, India.

Every wall tells a tale. Ajanta Caves, Maharashtra, India.

Exquisite work in stone. Ajanta Caves, Maharashtra, India.

Towering above all. Ajanta Caves, Maharashtra, India.

Arches. Ajanta Caves, Maharashtra, India.

A journey back in time. Ajanta Caves, Maharashtra, India.

A sprawling museum. Ajanta Caves, Maharashtra, India.

A security guard at one of the caves looked at me quizzically and asked why I had returned to the site. He remembered me from the previous day – perhaps I was spending too much time here?! Oh well, maybe I have a striking face ;).

While some muralsÂ have faded away, others are faint, and a few are clearly visible. Walls, pillars, and even ceilings are covered with stunning art. So remember to look in all directions – the rewards are infinite. Don’t hesitate to step back, turn around, or retrace a path. There’s always another discovery to be made.

Different views. Ajanta Caves, Maharashtra, India.

After a few hours, we reluctantly stepped onto the small bridge and took theÂ short route toward the exit.Â We paused often to turn back and glance at the magnificent caves. Would we return? Maybe. If not, we could travel back in time, trace the imprints in our mind. The murals, the sculptures, the grandeur, and the beauty had been etched deeply into myÂ memory.

Looking back. Ajanta Caves, Maharashtra, India.

 

The Ajanta Caves lie at a distance of about 100 km from Aurangabad. The site is a popular attraction among visitors of various nationalities. For an immersive experience, consider setting aside a couple of days to visit all the caves. If you are visiting for a day, some caves can be prioritized over the others (based on your interest).

item.description:
Lost and Found:

AtÂ theÂ vantage point atop a hill, a marvelousÂ sight unfolded in front of our eyes.Â AÂ beautiful horse-shoe-shaped gorge framed byÂ a dusty brown background. A series of rock-cut caves embedded along the U-shaped curve in the hillside. It was here that John Smith, while on a hunting expedition in 1819, discovered the existence of the Ajanta Caves, a site that had disappeared into oblivion for a long time.

Lost and found. A panoramic view of the Ajanta Caves, India.

Today, the 29 caves at Ajanta offer visitors a precious opportunity to exploreÂ Buddhism through magnificent sculptures and art. These ancient caves (dating as far back as the 2nd century BC) are a history and architecture lover’s dream come true. The chaitya grihas and viharas at Ajanta are a treasure trove of stories…Â some well known, othersÂ waiting to be told and heard.

 

The Plan:

After an amazing journey of discovery at the Ellora Caves the previous year, it was time to complete the circuit by visiting the Ajanta Caves. And so, weÂ set off on a trip to Ajanta.

After a long drive from Pune to Ajanta (~350 km), we checked in at MTDC’sÂ Ajanta Tourist Resort (MTDC), Fardapur. The room was clean and comfortable, the outdoor areaÂ was brightÂ and spacious, andÂ the kids play area was an instant winner with Junior.

For an immersive experience, we plannedÂ to explore the caves over two days. This decision helped us observe and appreciateÂ the art and architecture of the expansive site at a leisurely pace. With the unhurried approach, we were able to avoid fatigue, overwhelm, and the intense afternoon heat. Although many visitors manage to visit the site in a single day, the two-day itinerary worked well for our family.

Reflective moments. Ajanta Caves, India.

 

Day 1, Zooming In at the Ajanta Caves:

On ourÂ first day at the UNESCO World Heritage Site, we boarded the shuttle to the caves. As the busÂ moved ahead, we were struck by the remoteness of the location. A 15-minute ride took us toÂ the site entrance, where the ticket counter was buzzing with activity. Armed with our tickets, water bottles, and caps, we headed to explore theÂ numerous caves.

Our first destination was the last cave, Cave 26. We walked past all the other caves (encountering amused and curious glances from guards and some tourists) to reach the last one. To see the magnificent reclining Buddha. And from Cave 26, we began our journey of discovery. Over the next three to four hours, we listened to the storiesÂ narrated by every cave, from Cave 26 to Cave 11. And what an amazing journey it was! While detailed information aboutÂ each cave isÂ available at AjantaCaves.com and Wikipedia, I have chosen a few photographs to describe our experience.

The reclining Buddha. Cave 26, Ajanta Caves, India.

Architectural marvel. Cave 21, Ajanta Caves, India.

Grand entrance. Cave 19, Ajanta Caves, India.

Treasures from the past. Ajanta Caves, India.

Indelible impressions. Ajanta Caves, India.

In search of peace. Ajanta Caves, India.

Inscriptions. Ajanta Caves, India.

Art gallery. Ajanta Caves, India.

Stories galore. Ajanta Caves, India.

Invaluable treasures. Ajanta Caves, India.

 

Zooming Out at the Viewpoint:

In the evening, we visited the spotÂ that offers a fantastic distant view of the Ajanta Caves. The panorama from the viewpoint wasÂ the perfect end to our busy day. This place is locatedÂ at a distance of about 10 km from Ajanta.

Bird’s-eye view. Ajanta Caves Viewpoint, India.

The Ajanta Caves lie at a distance of about 100 km from Aurangabad. The site is a popular attraction among visitors of various nationalities. For an immersive experience, consider setting aside a couple of days to visit all the caves. If you are visiting for a day, some caves can be prioritized over the others (based on your interest).

item.description:
Tucked away in the hills. The Buddhist caves, Ellora, Maharashtra, India

A Much-awaited Trip

The UNESCO world heritage site of Ellora isÂ aÂ weekend escape or long-weekend getawayÂ from Pune.Â The splendid rock-cut caves had been on our wish list for quite some time. Along came the opportunity to pay a visit to this famous location.

Of the 34 rock-cut caves at Ellora, 17 are Hindu caves (cave numbers 13Â toÂ 29), 12 are Buddhist caves (cave numbersÂ 1-12), and 5 are Jain caves (cave numbersÂ 30-34).

The awe-inspiring monolithic Kailasanatha temple and the Dashavatar cave are among the numerous splendid masterpieces dedicated to Hinduism.Â The first part of this blog series describes these marvels.

OnÂ our journey of discovery, in addition to the Hindu caves, the caves dedicated to Buddhism and Jainism left an indelible impression on our minds.

 

The Buddhist Caves: MasterpiecesÂ in Stone

The “Do Tal” and “Teen Tal” are multi-level caves. As we explored each level, we came face-to-face with impressive sculptures of Buddhas and Bodhisattvas. Â The Carpenter’s Cave or Sutar Jhopadi (cave 10) isÂ the piÃ¨ce de rÃ©sistance of the Buddhist group of caves. AÂ high vaulted ceiling, magnificentÂ carvings that resembleÂ wooden beamsÂ andÂ aÂ majestic Buddha statue are the highlights of this masterpiece. In the chaitya griha, we were treated to a beautifulÂ rendition of the Buddham Saranam Gacchami chant by a guide (it was intended for some VIP guests, and, as luck would have it, we were present at that time! ðŸ™‚ ). TheÂ soothing chant rippled throughÂ the silent hall and magnified the intensity of our wonder and amazement. A fantastic experience! In a trance, we proceeded to the other caves.Â Junior was intrigued by the goddess in one of the sculpturesÂ in Cave 6. Mahamayuri, the Buddhist deityÂ of learning, is flanked byÂ a peacock. Outside, aÂ small waterfall flowed down the rocky hillside near the southern end of the Buddhist caves. It lent a special, almost magical, effect to the scene.

Mahamayuri, the Buddhist deity of wisdom. Cave 6, Ellora, Maharashtra, India

One, two, three! Teen Taal (Three Floors), Cave 12, Ellora, Maharashtra, India

All in a row. Inside Cave 12, Ellora, Maharashtra, India

 

The spectacular Carpenter’s Cave. Cave 16, Ellora, Maharashtra, India

 

The Jain Caves: OrnateÂ Art in Stone

After visitingÂ the Hindu and Buddhist caves, we were quite tired (having walked for several hours and having exploredÂ almost every nook of every cave). I even wondered aloud aboutÂ the option ofÂ visiting the remaining caves the next day. Junior, to my surprise, admonished me for even considering that thought! HeÂ was enthusiastic about continuing our exploration and seemed determined to visit the last group. And so it was decided. We took an autorickshaw to the Jain group of caves, located at the northern end of the complex.

Although the Jain caves are relatively smaller,Â the ornate and detailed art in theseÂ caves is a delight to the eyes. Fragments of colored art are still visible, leaving the grandeur of the original work to our imagination. The intricate designs and beautiful sculptures of GomatesvaraÂ andÂ the Tirthankaras capture the visitor’s attention.Â It was a fitting finale to a wonderful day of exploration.

 

Sculptures in the Jain caves. Ellora, Maharashtra, India

Looking out. Jain caves, Ellora, Maharashtra, India

Attention to detail. Jain caves, Ellora, Maharashtra, India

 

Useful Information
– The Ellora caves complex is closed to visitors on Tuesday

– Autorickshaws are available for touring the caves. The Hindu and the Buddhist caves can be covered by foot. They extend on either side of the main entrance to the complex. However,Â the Jain group of caves is approximately 2 kilometers away from the main complex and it is convenient to hire an auto to get there.

– There is a small restaurant outside the complex. We preferred to carryÂ a packed lunch.

item.title: [Ellora, Maharashtra, India] Discovering the Exquisite Treasures of Ellora â€“ I
item.description:
AÂ Dream

For several years, B and I have talked about a visit to the Ajanta and Ellora caves someday. After our move to Pune, these architectural wonders were much closer to home. It didn’t take us long to plan a trip to the Ellora caves.

Ellora caves, also known as Verul Leni, is a marvellous complex of rock-cut temples and monasteries. ThisÂ UNESCO world heritage site is located approximately 30 kilometers from Aurangabad in Maharashtra.

 

En Route

TheÂ drive from Aurangabad to Ellora took us past theÂ Daulatabad Fort (a hike for another day). At Ellora, B was looking forward to exploring the Buddhist caves while Junior was excited about the Dashavatar cave and other sculptures from Hindu mythology. I was very curious about the famous Kailasa temple. With much anticipation and eagerness, we reached the historical site.

 

Daulatabad Fort. En route to the Ellora Caves, Maharashtra, India

The Ellora Caves, an Architectural Marvel

The sprawling complex at Ellora consists of 34 rock-cut caves carved fromÂ volcanic basalt rock. Dating from the 6th centuryÂ ADÂ to the 10th century AD, theseÂ beautiful masterpieces have been built by the Kalachuri, the Rashtrakuta, the Chalukya, and the Yadava dynasties.

The ancient site hasÂ 17 Hindu caves (cave numbers 13Â toÂ 29), 12 Buddhist caves (cave numbersÂ 1-12), and 5 Jain caves (cave numbersÂ 30-34).

 

The Hindu Caves:Â A Fascinating Journey through Stories

Our day of exploration began at the imposing Cave 16, not just an ordinary cave. It is the towering Kailasanatha temple or Kailasa temple. Painstakingly carved from a single rock, this multi-storied structure represents Mount Kailash, Lord Shiva’s abode. I was awed by the architecture, to say the least. We walked around and up and down, admiring the Nandi, paying obeisance to the Shivalingam, identifying various mythological stories in the friezes, and trying to imagine the extent of planning and hard work that created this fantastic temple. The construction is said to have spanned a period of 200 years, and the area of this marvelÂ is double the size of the Parthenon in Greece.

The magnificent Kailasa temple. Ellora caves, Maharashtra, India

The magnificent Kailasa temple. Ellora caves, Maharashtra, India

The magnificent Kailasa temple. Ellora caves, Maharashtra, India

Stories from mythology at the magnificent Kailasa temple. Ellora caves, Maharashtra, India

After that spectacular start, we moved on to Cave 15. Here, Junior was on his toes, moving from one depiction to another.Â Amar Chitra Katha’s Dashavatar is one of his favorite books.Â AlthoughÂ JuniorÂ was eager to view the depictions of the ten avatars, heÂ had to be satisfied with the five incarnations in the cave.

Varaha Avatar. Ellora caves, Maharashtra, India

Narasimha Avatar. Ellora caves, Maharashtra, India

Cave 14 captured our attention next. The river goddesses Ganga and Yamuna stand guard at the entrance. Our favorite discoveryÂ in this cave wasÂ the beautiful sculptures of the Saptamatrikas with their chubby babies. The mood changed to a serious one when we sighted the depiction of the goddesses of death,Â Kala and Kali.

The other notable Hindu caves were Cave 21 with its spectacular scenes of Shiva and Parvati’s wedding and Cave 29 (on the other side of the gorge) with the representation of Shiva battlingÂ Ravana’s attempts to shakeÂ Mount Kailash.

The wedding of Shiva and Parvati. Ellora Caves, Maharashtra, India

Ravana’s attempts to shake Mount Kailash. Ellora Caves, Maharashtra, India

If the Hindu caves left us with a sense of amazement and wonder, the Buddhist and Jain caves at Ellora were not too far behind. Stay tuned for the second blog post in this series on the Ellora caves.
